column5: Reason

column2: Workload is spread over the whole team (one team member is often Xtimes more productive than the others...but nevertheless, here is a track record that everyone is contributing a lot)
Number of commits: by different people
column5: Different members committing can be seen in the period of Sep-Oct 2020
Most of the issues are documentation related with very few bugs
All issues have been closed

column2: Docs: doco generated, format not ugly
column5: Although there is enough documentation, it is not sufficient to execute the code easily

column2: Docs: what: point descriptions of each class/function (in isolation)
column5: None of the codes have description/comments to explain the functionality of the code

column2: Docs: how: for common use cases X,Y,Z mini-tutorials showing worked examples on how to do X,Y,Z
column5: Only screenshots provided. No description of what each functionality does

column2: Docs: why: docs tell a story, motivate the whole thing, deliver a punchline that makes you want to rush out and use the thing
column5: Repo is not extremely attractive. Basic information of the tool is provided with screenshots.

column2: Docs: short video, animated, hosted on your repo. That convinces people why they want to work on your code.

column5: Github is used
flake8, pylint used
black, prettier used and style checkers
flake8, pylint used
No code coverage used
No evidence of automated tools
Basic test cases exist
No routine execution to check code

column2: The files CONTRIBUTING.md lists coding standards and lots of tips on how to extend the system without screwing things up
column5: Just a few regulations mentioned, no proper guidelines set to make sure that the people working on the code can adhere to.

column2: Issues are discussed before they are closed
column5: Since the issues are just a few bugs, enhancements, there's no proper comment section to observe
No chat channel

column2: Test cases: a large proportion of the issues related to handling failing cases.
Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools: everyone can get to all tools and files
Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools (e.g. config files in the repo, updated by lots of different people)
Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools (e.g. tutor can ask anyone to share screen, they demonstrate the system running on their computer)
Evidence that the members of the team are working across multiple places in the code base

column5: Code hasn't been worked on since 2020. And only two versions are available.
